flores_passage: When a small subset of living things (a small population of them) is separated from their main group (such as when they cross over a mountain or river, or when they go to a new island and cannot easily return), they often find themselves in a different environment from the one they were in before. This new place has different resources and different competitors, so the new group needs different adaptations or to get used to the new place in order to be more competitive than they needed to be before. The initial number of individuals has not changed; they still need to adapt to the environment as before. Over time, as most of the group gets used to the new place, they start to differ more and more from other groups. Eventually, after thousands or even millions of years, the two groups will be so different that we can no longer call them the same species. We call this process "Speciation." This means the creation of new species. "Speciation" is an important process in the evolution and change of living things.
question: According to the paragraph, which of the following examples can hinder the process of natural selection?

flores_passage: Sundarbans is the largest contiguous mangrove forest in the world, spanning 80 kilometers and stretching across Bangladesh and India from the sea. These forests are not just waterlogged areas; there are also regions that were once covered by dense, green forests. Sundarbans covers an area of 3,850 km², with about one-third of it being waterlogged areas. Sundarbans has been a wildlife sanctuary since 1966. Today, it is estimated to have around 400 Royal Bengal tigers and approximately 30,000 deer.
